flow.descriptionCdata:
6b9cfc5d-d429-4421-bcd2-64097784e304.0e84f0d3-f125-4bab-9eaa-b19e9aece73e.description=
This operation does not do anything. It can be used to filter flow variables by defining them as inputs and filtering them in the Results tab.

Inputs\:
    field1 – An optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.
    field2 – An optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.
    field3 – An optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.
    field4 – An optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.

Results\:
    returnResult - This is the primary output. It contains the value of  "field1" as it was specified at input or when filtered. 

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
6b9cfc5d-d429-4421-bcd2-64097784e304.1cffa3e5-a636-4392-84c7-e748ac0779d0.description=This operation runs a SQL command. Inputs\: DBServerName - The hostname or ip address of the database server. DbType - The type of database to connect to. Valid values\: Oracle, MSSQL, Sybase, Netcool, DB2, PostgreSQL and Custom. Default value\: Oracle Username - The username to use when connecting to the database. Password - The password to use when connecting to the database. instance - The name instance (for MSSQL Server). Leave it blank for default instance. DbPort - The port to connect to. Default values\: Oracle\: 1521, MSSQL\: 1433, Sybase\: 5000, Netcool\: 4100, DB2\: 50000, PostgreSQL\: 5432. Database - The name of the database. authenticationType - The type of authentication used to access the database (applicable only to MSSQL type). Valid values\: sql, windows (for MSSQL) Default value\: sql dbClass - The classname of the JDBC driver to use. dbURL - The url required to load up the driver and make your connection. ssl - Specifies if the communication will be encrypted using Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) (only applicable for PostgreSQL). Valid values\: true, false SSLMode - Specifies the different levels of protection SSL can provide. If the ssl input is set to true, SSLMode must be specified, otherwise it will be ignored (only applicable for PostgreSQL). Valid values\: allow, prefer, require, verify-ca, verify-full SSLCert - Specifies the full path for the certificate file (only applicable for PostgreSQL). SSLKey - Specifies the full path for the key file which must be in DER format. Check the notes section for more details about conversion to DER format (only applicable for PostgreSQL). SSLRootCert - Specifies the full path of the SSL root certificate (only applicable for PostgreSQL). Command - The command to execute. timeout - Seconds to wait before timing out the SQL command execution. When the default value is used, there is no limit on the amount of time allowed for a running command to complete. Default value\: 0 databasePoolingProperties - Properties for database pooling configuration. This parameter replaces the databasePooling.properties file from 9x version (you may copy-paste the file content here). Pooling is disabled by default. For more details check the /Library/Operations/Database/JDBC folder description. Example\: db.pooling.enable\=true resultSetType - the result set type. See JDBC folder description for more details. Valid values\: TYPE_FORWARD_ONLY, TYPE_SCROLL_INSENSITIVE,TYPE_SCROLL_SENSITIVE. Default value\: TYPE_FORWARD_ONLY resultSetConcurrency - the result set concurrency. See JDBC folder description for more details. Valid values\: CONCUR_READ_ONLY, CONCUR_UPDATABLE Default value\: CONCUR_READ_ONLY Results\: returnResult - This is the primary output. It contains the "Command completed successfully" message if the operation succeeded, or a failure message otherwise. outputText - The return result of SQL command. updateCount - The update count of the command executed. Responses\: success - The command was executed successfully. failure - Failed to execute the command. Notes\: 1. Check the JDBC folder description for details on how to load database connectors. 2. In case of using subprograms like (GET_LINE, GET_LINES, NEW_LINE, PUT, PUT_LUNE) from DBMS_OUTPUT package, the DBMS_OUTPUT.ENABLE() declaration should be used before of these calls. 3. Use the 'Command' input with caution as it can expose the target system to security risks. By exposing the 'Command' input as a prompt to the user, it will enable the user to execute any SQL command on the target system taking into account the permissions of the credentials given as inputs. 4. SSL encryption only works for PostgreSQL. 5. Database pooling is not supported when "ssl"\=true (only applicable for PostgreSQL). 6. A PEM key can be converted to DER format using the openssl command\: openssl pkcs8 -topk8 -inform PEM -in my.key -outform DER -out my.key.der. 7. For information on how to generate certificates, how to setup the postgress server to accept SSL connections and supported SSL modes please refer to the PostgreSQL official documentation. 8. Steps for creating the SSL certificates can be found in the CP's release notes, under the "Use" section. Note\: Check the JDBC folder description for details on how to load database connectors. 6b9cfc5d-d429-4421-bcd2-64097784e304.25eab319-0433-4fdb-82bd-78c6400d01cc.prompt=Enter new last_name\: 6b9cfc5d-d429-4421-bcd2-64097784e304.3a7d2242-1701-4ec9-8e6c-f68fe999812e.prompt=Enter id for update\: 6b9cfc5d-d429-4421-bcd2-64097784e304.7e63d836-b869-4fc5-a402-2380f68d224f.prompt=Enter new first_name\: 6b9cfc5d-d429-4421-bcd2-64097784e304.7faa631b-3ef3-4ec5-9d49-7b5208c0b1b2.description=This operation runs a SQL command. Inputs\: DBServerName - The hostname or ip address of the database server. DbType - The type of database to connect to. Valid values\: Oracle, MSSQL, Sybase, Netcool, DB2, PostgreSQL and Custom. Default value\: Oracle Username - The username to use when connecting to the database. Password - The password to use when connecting to the database. instance - The name instance (for MSSQL Server). Leave it blank for default instance. DbPort - The port to connect to. Default values\: Oracle\: 1521, MSSQL\: 1433, Sybase\: 5000, Netcool\: 4100, DB2\: 50000, PostgreSQL\: 5432. Database - The name of the database. authenticationType - The type of authentication used to access the database (applicable only to MSSQL type). Valid values\: sql, windows (for MSSQL) Default value\: sql dbClass - The classname of the JDBC driver to use. dbURL - The url required to load up the driver and make your connection. ssl - Specifies if the communication will be encrypted using Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) (only applicable for PostgreSQL). Valid values\: true, false SSLMode - Specifies the different levels of protection SSL can provide. If the ssl input is set to true, SSLMode must be specified, otherwise it will be ignored (only applicable for PostgreSQL). Valid values\: allow, prefer, require, verify-ca, verify-full SSLCert - Specifies the full path for the certificate file (only applicable for PostgreSQL). SSLKey - Specifies the full path for the key file which must be in DER format. Check the notes section for more details about conversion to DER format (only applicable for PostgreSQL). SSLRootCert - Specifies the full path of the SSL root certificate (only applicable for PostgreSQL). Command - The command to execute. timeout - Seconds to wait before timing out the SQL command execution. When the default value is used, there is no limit on the amount of time allowed for a running command to complete. Default value\: 0 databasePoolingProperties - Properties for database pooling configuration. This parameter replaces the databasePooling.properties file from 9x version (you may copy-paste the file content here). Pooling is disabled by default. For more details check the /Library/Operations/Database/JDBC folder description. Example\: db.pooling.enable\=true resultSetType - the result set type. See JDBC folder description for more details. Valid values\: TYPE_FORWARD_ONLY, TYPE_SCROLL_INSENSITIVE,TYPE_SCROLL_SENSITIVE. Default value\: TYPE_FORWARD_ONLY resultSetConcurrency - the result set concurrency. See JDBC folder description for more details. Valid values\: CONCUR_READ_ONLY, CONCUR_UPDATABLE Default value\: CONCUR_READ_ONLY Results\: returnResult - This is the primary output. It contains the "Command completed successfully" message if the operation succeeded, or a failure message otherwise. outputText - The return result of SQL command. updateCount - The update count of the command executed. Responses\: success - The command was executed successfully. failure - Failed to execute the command. Notes\: 1. Check the JDBC folder description for details on how to load database connectors. 2. In case of using subprograms like (GET_LINE, GET_LINES, NEW_LINE, PUT, PUT_LUNE) from DBMS_OUTPUT package, the DBMS_OUTPUT.ENABLE() declaration should be used before of these calls. 3. Use the 'Command' input with caution as it can expose the target system to security risks. By exposing the 'Command' input as a prompt to the user, it will enable the user to execute any SQL command on the target system taking into account the permissions of the credentials given as inputs. 4. SSL encryption only works for PostgreSQL. 5. Database pooling is not supported when "ssl"\=true (only applicable for PostgreSQL). 6. A PEM key can be converted to DER format using the openssl command\: openssl pkcs8 -topk8 -inform PEM -in my.key -outform DER -out my.key.der. 7. For information on how to generate certificates, how to setup the postgress server to accept SSL connections and supported SSL modes please refer to the PostgreSQL official documentation. 8. Steps for creating the SSL certificates can be found in the CP's release notes, under the "Use" section. Note\: Check the JDBC folder description for details on how to load database connectors. 6b9cfc5d-d429-4421-bcd2-64097784e304.9626e8c5-9756-406c-b23f-236ca89581db.description=

Displays a message to the user.

Inputs\:
  message - The message text to display
  title - The title on the message window. Defaults to "Status message".

Responses\:
  Always returns success.

Examples\:
  In order to display the message "Finished" to the user, go to the 
  detail screen for the input named "message" and change the Otherwise option
  from Prompt User to Use Constant.  Then enter the text "Finished" into the
  Constant Value field.

  References to flow variables in the Contant Value field are expanded so that
  the text may be dynamic.  Flow variable references are of the form
  ${variable}.  For example, the text\:
     ${count} systems were modified 
  could be used to display a message about the number of systems that were
  repaired, whose value is in the flow variable "count".

  When the message is displayed, it will properly render any embedded html
  tags, which permits creating messages with more advanced formatting.  For 
  example to display a message in italics you could use\:
    This is important
  or to display a message in red\:
    This is really  important

  You can create messages that contain multiple lines by entering a multiple
  line message in the Constant Value field, or by using HTML 
 tags for line
  breaks.  Note that \n characters are displayed literally and are not used for
  creating multiple lines.
6b9cfc5d-d429-4421-bcd2-64097784e304.bf45bcee-8b79-4845-9f0f-82e5156063cf.description=This operation runs a SQL command. Inputs\: DBServerName - The hostname or ip address of the database server. DbType - The type of database to connect to. Valid values\: Oracle, MSSQL, Sybase, Netcool, DB2, PostgreSQL and Custom. Default value\: Oracle Username - The username to use when connecting to the database. Password - The password to use when connecting to the database. instance - The name instance (for MSSQL Server). Leave it blank for default instance. DbPort - The port to connect to. Default values\: Oracle\: 1521, MSSQL\: 1433, Sybase\: 5000, Netcool\: 4100, DB2\: 50000, PostgreSQL\: 5432. Database - The name of the database. authenticationType - The type of authentication used to access the database (applicable only to MSSQL type). Valid values\: sql, windows (for MSSQL) Default value\: sql dbClass - The classname of the JDBC driver to use. dbURL - The url required to load up the driver and make your connection. ssl - Specifies if the communication will be encrypted using Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) (only applicable for PostgreSQL). Valid values\: true, false SSLMode - Specifies the different levels of protection SSL can provide. If the ssl input is set to true, SSLMode must be specified, otherwise it will be ignored (only applicable for PostgreSQL). Valid values\: allow, prefer, require, verify-ca, verify-full SSLCert - Specifies the full path for the certificate file (only applicable for PostgreSQL). SSLKey - Specifies the full path for the key file which must be in DER format. Check the notes section for more details about conversion to DER format (only applicable for PostgreSQL). SSLRootCert - Specifies the full path of the SSL root certificate (only applicable for PostgreSQL). Command - The command to execute. timeout - Seconds to wait before timing out the SQL command execution. When the default value is used, there is no limit on the amount of time allowed for a running command to complete. Default value\: 0 databasePoolingProperties - Properties for database pooling configuration. This parameter replaces the databasePooling.properties file from 9x version (you may copy-paste the file content here). Pooling is disabled by default. For more details check the /Library/Operations/Database/JDBC folder description. Example\: db.pooling.enable\=true resultSetType - the result set type. See JDBC folder description for more details. Valid values\: TYPE_FORWARD_ONLY, TYPE_SCROLL_INSENSITIVE,TYPE_SCROLL_SENSITIVE. Default value\: TYPE_FORWARD_ONLY resultSetConcurrency - the result set concurrency. See JDBC folder description for more details. Valid values\: CONCUR_READ_ONLY, CONCUR_UPDATABLE Default value\: CONCUR_READ_ONLY Results\: returnResult - This is the primary output. It contains the "Command completed successfully" message if the operation succeeded, or a failure message otherwise. outputText - The return result of SQL command. updateCount - The update count of the command executed. Responses\: success - The command was executed successfully. failure - Failed to execute the command. Notes\: 1. Check the JDBC folder description for details on how to load database connectors. 2. In case of using subprograms like (GET_LINE, GET_LINES, NEW_LINE, PUT, PUT_LUNE) from DBMS_OUTPUT package, the DBMS_OUTPUT.ENABLE() declaration should be used before of these calls. 3. Use the 'Command' input with caution as it can expose the target system to security risks. By exposing the 'Command' input as a prompt to the user, it will enable the user to execute any SQL command on the target system taking into account the permissions of the credentials given as inputs. 4. SSL encryption only works for PostgreSQL. 5. Database pooling is not supported when "ssl"\=true (only applicable for PostgreSQL). 6. A PEM key can be converted to DER format using the openssl command\: openssl pkcs8 -topk8 -inform PEM -in my.key -outform DER -out my.key.der. 7. For information on how to generate certificates, how to setup the postgress server to accept SSL connections and supported SSL modes please refer to the PostgreSQL official documentation. 8. Steps for creating the SSL certificates can be found in the CP's release notes, under the "Use" section. Note\: Check the JDBC folder description for details on how to load database connectors. 6b9cfc5d-d429-4421-bcd2-64097784e304.eb389d59-cc1c-45b7-8a09-ec092bb06e2d.description=

Displays a message to the user.

Inputs\:
  message - The message text to display
  title - The title on the message window. Defaults to "Status message".

Responses\:
  Always returns success.

Examples\:
  In order to display the message "Finished" to the user, go to the 
  detail screen for the input named "message" and change the Otherwise option
  from Prompt User to Use Constant.  Then enter the text "Finished" into the
  Constant Value field.

  References to flow variables in the Contant Value field are expanded so that
  the text may be dynamic.  Flow variable references are of the form
  ${variable}.  For example, the text\:
     ${count} systems were modified 
  could be used to display a message about the number of systems that were
  repaired, whose value is in the flow variable "count".

  When the message is displayed, it will properly render any embedded html
  tags, which permits creating messages with more advanced formatting.  For 
  example to display a message in italics you could use\:
    This is important
  or to display a message in red\:
    This is really  important

  You can create messages that contain multiple lines by entering a multiple
  line message in the Constant Value field, or by using HTML 
 tags for line
  breaks.  Note that \n characters are displayed literally and are not used for
  creating multiple lines.
flow.name: update_flow

staticBinding.value: update actor set first_name='${fname}', last_name='${lname}' where actor_id=${id};
